questions.text: A 65 year old chronic smoker came to the medicine OPD with complaints of upper chest discomfort and drooping of an eyelid. He also complained of pain radiating to the upper arm and a tingling sensation in the 4th and 5th digits of his left hand. The chest x-ray is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A chronic alcoholic patient presents with acute pain and swelling of the left great toe. There is no history of trauma. Synovial fluid analysis shows raised leukocytes. Lab investigations show normal serum uric acid levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A patient presented with acute onset of left sided weakness and loss of proprioception and vibration sense over left side of the body with facial sparing. On protrusion of tongue, it deviates to the right side. Which artery is involved:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The clinical features described—acute onset left-sided weakness, loss of proprioception and vibration sense on the left side of the body, and facial sparing—are highly indicative of a medial medullary syndrome (also known as Dejerine syndrome), which is caused by an infarction in the region supplied by the anterior spinal artery. The anterior spinal artery supplies the medial portion of the medulla, where the pyramidal tract (for motor function) and medial lemniscus (for proprioception and vibration sense) are located. The deviation of the tongue to the right on protrusion indicates right-sided hypoglossal nerve involvement, as the hypoglossal nerve nuclei are also located in the medulla. Thus, the anterior spinal artery is the artery most commonly involved in this type of presentation, causing both motor and sensory deficits with facial sparing.
  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • A. Middle Cerebral Artery – Incorrect:
  • • The middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies most of the lateral convexity of the cerebral hemisphere, including areas responsible for motor and sensory functions of the face, arm, and hand. However, the MCA does not supply the medulla or the structures described in this case (proprioception, vibration sense, and hypoglossal nerve function). MCA involvement would typically result in contralateral hemiparesis, sensory loss, and facial involvement, unlike the facial sparing seen in this case. Therefore, the MCA is not the correct answer.
  • • B. Anterior Cerebral Artery – Incorrect:
  • • The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) supplies the medial aspect of the frontal lobes and the paracentral lobule, which is involved in motor and sensory functions of the contralateral leg and foot. ACA occlusion can cause contralateral leg weakness or sensory loss, but it does not affect the medulla or structures such as the hypoglossal nerve or medial lemniscus. Additionally, there would likely be involvement of the leg, not sparing of the face, which further rules out the ACA as the cause of this patient’s symptoms.
  • • C. Posterior Cerebral Artery – Incorrect:
  • • The posterior cerebral artery (PCA) supplies the occipital lobe and the inferior temporal lobe, as well as portions of the thalamus and midbrain. While PCA occlusion can result in visual deficits (e.g., homonymous hemianopia) or thalamic sensory disturbances, it does not supply the medulla where the structures involved in the patient's symptoms are located. Therefore, PCA involvement is not associated with the symptoms of weakness, proprioceptive loss, and hypoglossal nerve deviation seen here.

questions.text: A Patient with History of RTA presented to the OPD after 3 days. CT showed the presence of an SDH. On fundoscopy B/L papilledema was seen. What is the most probable course of this:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • B. Meningitis – Incorrect: Meningitis can cause raised ICP and papilledema, but it typically presents with fever, neck stiffness, photophobia, and altered mental status, which are not mentioned here. Additionally, there is a clear traumatic etiology and imaging confirmation of SDH, making raised ICP due to mass effect more likely. C. Optic Neuritis – Incorrect: Optic neuritis presents with unilateral vision loss, pain on eye movement, and sometimes changes in color vision. It does not cause bilateral papilledema or result from trauma or SDH. Moreover, optic disc swelling in optic neuritis is usually unilateral and not due to raised ICP. D. Glaucoma – Incorrect: Glaucoma is an eye condition involving increased intraocular pressure, not intracranial pressure. It typically presents with visual field defects and optic disc cupping, not papilledema. It is unrelated to trauma or SDH.

A bronchial asthma patient on inhalational steroids presented with white patchy lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa. What is the drug that can be used to treat this condition?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Terbinafine: Also mainly active against dermatophytes, not Candida.
  • • Flucytosine: Used for systemic Candida or Cryptococcus infections, usually in serious invasive cases (often with amphotericin B), not for localized oral thrush.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with history of bronchial asthma is in the third stage of labour. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in the management of postpartum hemorrhage in this mother?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • While effective in controlling PPH, it is contraindicated in patients with asthma because it can cause bronchoconstriction, which may trigger a life-threatening asthma attack. Other options: Oxytocin: First-line agent in PPH; safe in asthma.
  • • Dinoprostone (PGE2 analogue): Can be used cautiously, though it may have mild bronchoconstrictive effects, it is generally considered safer than PGF2α analogues. Methyl ergometrine: Contraindicated in hypertension, not asthma (use cautiously if coexisting conditions exist, but not absolutely contraindicated in asthma).

questions.text: Name the drug that inhibits both Angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) and neural endopeptidase?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme (ACE) – which converts angiotensin I to angiotensin II, a potent vasoconstrictor. Neutral endopeptidase (also called neprilysin) – which breaks down natriuretic peptides like ANP and BNP that promote vasodilation and natriuresis. Clinical Significance: By inhibiting both enzymes, omapatrilat offers dual action: reducing vasoconstriction and enhancing vasodilation. It was developed for use in heart failure and hypertension.
  • • However, it was withdrawn from development due to a higher incidence of angioedema, likely because both ACE and neprilysin break down bradykinin — leading to its accumulation when both are inhibited. Other options: A. Sacubitril: Inhibits neprilysin only. Often combined with valsartan (an ARB) in heart failure treatment. B. Losartan: An angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB); does not inhibit ACE or neprilysin.
  • • C. Nesiritide: A recombinant B-type natriuretic peptide, used in acute decompensated heart failure; it mimics but does not inhibit neprilysin or ACE.

questions.text: A patient with a previous history of myocardial infarction and ventricular arrhythmia is on treatment for a few months. He developed fatigue, dyspnea and weight gain. He had also developed pulmonary fibrosis. Which of the following drugs is responsible for these side effects?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Skin changes: Photosensitivity, blue-gray skin discoloration. Neurologic symptoms: Tremor, ataxia, neuropathy. Ocular toxicity Cardiovascular effects: Bradycardia and hypotension. Patient Clues Matching Amiodarone Toxicity: Fatigue, dyspnea, weight gain: Can indicate hypothyroidism or heart failure worsening. Pulmonary fibrosis: Classic and serious complication of long-term amiodarone therapy. History of MI and ventricular arrhythmia: Typical indication for starting amiodarone. Why Not the Others? Atenolol: Beta-blocker; may cause fatigue and bradycardia, but not pulmonary fibrosis. Aspirin: Can cause GI bleeding or asthma exacerbation, not pulmonary fibrosis. Spironolactone: Can cause gynecomastia and hyperkalemia, not pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text: A young female comes to the emergency department after consuming 100 tablets of Aspirin. What should be the next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: N-acetyl cysteine to replenish glutamine stores

options.label: C
options.text: Glucagon to control bradycardia and hypoglycemia

options.label: D
options.text: Sodium bicarbonate to alkalize the urine

questions.correct_answer: D. Sodium bicarbonate to alkalize the urine
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Reduce salicylate absorption Enhance salicylate elimination Correct acid-base and fluid-electrolyte disturbances Key intervention: Sodium bicarbonate: This is used to alkalinize the urine, which increases the ionized form of salicylate, reducing its reabsorption in the renal tubules and enhancing its excretion. Urinary alkalinization is the cornerstone of treatment in moderate to severe salicylate poisoning. Why not the others?
  • • A. N-acetylcysteine: Used for paracetamol (acetaminophen) overdose, not salicylates.
  • • B. Pralidoxime: Antidote for organophosphate poisoning, not aspirin.
  • • C. Glucagon: Used in beta-blocker or calcium channel blocker overdose, not aspirin.

questions.text: A chronic smoker was on nicotine replacement therapy and clonidine tablets for smoking deaddiction. He stopped taking clonidine tablets and now presents with a headache. What is the reason behind this condition?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The mechanism behind rebound hypertension is the upregulation of alpha-1 receptors due to chronic clonidine use, and without the drug, the increased sympathetic activity causes a surge in blood pressure. Why not the others? A. Postural hypotension: Clonidine can cause hypotension when first started or in excessive doses, but rebound hypertension is more likely after discontinuation. B. Receptor upregulation: While upregulation of receptors can occur with chronic clonidine use, the main issue after stopping the drug is rebound hypertension, not upregulation alone. D. Receptor hypersensitivity: This term is more commonly used in reference to other conditions (e.g., beta-receptor hypersensitivity in asthma), but it’s not the best description of what occurs after stopping clonidine.

questions.text: A patient with recurrent attacks of gout was started on a therapy that inhibits the synthesis of uric acid. His symptoms were reduced after therapy. Which drug was he started on?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • In gout, recurrent attacks occur due to elevated uric acid levels in the blood, which can crystallize and deposit in joints, causing inflammation. By inhibiting uric acid synthesis, allopurinol helps to prevent these attacks. Why not the others? A. Probenecid: This is a uricosuric agent that increases the excretion of uric acid by the kidneys, rather than inhibiting its production. It is used to manage gout in some cases but is not the drug of choice for reducing uric acid synthesis. B. Colchicine: Colchicine is used to treat acute gout attacks by reducing inflammation. However, it does not lower uric acid levels or prevent recurrent attacks long-term. D. Diclofenac: Diclofenac is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used to reduce the inflammation and pain associated with acute gout attacks, but it does not affect uric acid production or prevent recurrent attacks.

questions.text: A patient with malignancy is undergoing chemotherapy. The platelet counts were reduced after the previous cycle of chemotherapy. Which of the following drugs can be used in the treatment of this patient?
The true statement among the following is-

options.label: A
options.text: The dose of telmisartan should be reduced in renal failure but not in hepatic failure

options.label: B
options.text: The dose of irbesartan should be reduced in case of mild-moderate hepatic failure and renal failure.

options.label: C
options.text: The dose of candesartan should be reduced in mild-moderate liver failure but not in renal failure.

options.label: D
options.text: Losartan acts as thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation

questions.correct_answer: D. Losartan acts as thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Why not the others? A. The dose of telmisartan should be reduced in renal failure but not in hepatic failure: This is incorrect. Telmisartan, like other ARBs, requires dose adjustment in renal failure but does not typically require dose reduction in hepatic failure unless the patient has severe liver impairment. B. The dose of irbesartan should be reduced in case of mild-moderate hepatic failure and renal failure: This is incorrect. Irbesartan requires dose adjustment mainly in cases of severe renal failure. There is no need to reduce the dose in mild to moderate hepatic impairment unless there is severe hepatic dysfunction. C. The dose of candesartan should be reduced in mild-moderate liver failure but not in renal failure: This is incorrect. Candesartan should be adjusted in renal failure, especially in cases of severe renal dysfunction. It does not typically require dose adjustment in mild-moderate hepatic failure.

questions.text: A patient given digoxin started having side effects like nausea and vomiting. The serum concentration of digoxin was 4mg/dl. The plasma therapeutic range is 1mg/dl. If the half life of digoxin is 40 hours, how long should one wait before resuming the treatment?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Key Points: Therapeutic range of digoxin: 1 mg/dl. Current serum concentration: 4 mg/dl. Half-life of digoxin: 40 hours. The general formula to estimate the time it will take for a drug to decrease to a safe concentration is:
  • • Time to reach therapeutic level = Half-life × log 2 ( Current concentration Therapeutic concentration) Time to reach therapeutic level=Half-life×log 2 ( Therapeutic concentration Current concentration ) However, a simplified approach is to wait around 5 half-lives for a drug to drop close to a therapeutic range (for many drugs). This is because after 5 half-lives, the concentration typically falls by over 95%. Calculation: Given:
  • • Half-life of digoxin = 40 hours You would wait approximately 5 half-lives. 5 × 40 = 200 hours 5×40=200 hours However, this calculation suggests an extended period. For clinical practicality and rapid therapeutic adjustment, a closer approximation is usually 2 half-lives for initial symptom resolution and then reassessment. Hence, 80 hours (which is 2 half-lives) is a reasonable estimate for when to reconsider therapy.
  • • Why not the others? A. 40 hours: This would only cover one half-life, not enough time for digoxin to reach therapeutic levels.
  • • C. 120 hours: While longer than necessary, this is an overestimate and unnecessary for most patients. D. 140-180 hours: This is far too long and does not fit typical clinical guidelines for drug elimination.

questions.text: A patient comes to the casualty with organophosphate poisoning. He was started on atropine infusion and pralidoxime. After 2 hours, the patient had a sudden rise in temperature. What is the likely cause of fever?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • In cases of organophosphate poisoning, atropine is given to counteract the muscarinic effects of the poisoning, but if too much atropine is used, toxic effects can result, including fever, dry mouth, blurred vision, and urinary retention. Why not the others? B. Side effect of pralidoxime: Pralidoxime is used to reactivate acetylcholinesterase and reverse the effects of organophosphate poisoning. It generally does not cause a significant rise in temperature. C. Due to organophosphate poisoning: While organophosphates can cause muscarinic effects like excessive salivation, bronchorrhea, and bradycardia, fever is more commonly due to atropine toxicity rather than the poisoning itself. Organophosphate poisoning leads to hypothermia in some cases due to excessive cholinergic stimulation, rather than fever. D. Idiopathic: While fever can sometimes occur without a clear cause, in this case, the administration of atropine strongly suggests that the fever is likely due to atropine toxicity.

questions.text: The mechanism of action of tissue plasminogen activator is

After eating an unknown plant, a child was presented to the emergency with comatose status. The pupil were dilated and skin was dry. Body temperature was raised and the heart rate was high. These signs and symptoms can occur with the intake of which of the following substance?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Dhatura (Datura stramonium) is a plant known for its anticholinergic properties, which can cause delirium, hallucinations, dilated pupils, dry mouth, increased heart rate, elevated body temperature, and skin dryness. The alkaloids in dhatura (e.g., scopolamine, hyoscyamine) inhibit acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors, leading to these characteristic toxic effects. In severe cases, dhatura poisoning can result in coma and death due to its systemic effects.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Foxglove – Incorrect:
  • • Foxglove (digitalis) contains compounds called cardiac glycosides, which primarily affect the heart by inhibiting the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, leading to arrhythmias and bradycardia (slow heart rate), not symptoms like dry skin, elevated body temperature, or dilated pupils. The symptoms described are more characteristic of anticholinergic poisoning, not digitalis toxicity. B. Poppy seeds – Incorrect:
  • • Poppy seeds contain trace amounts of opioid alkaloids (such as morphine and codeine), but they are not known to cause the anticholinergic symptoms of dilated pupils, dry skin, and elevated body temperature. Opioid toxicity would cause miosis (constricted pupils), respiratory depression, and bradycardia, not the signs mentioned in the question. C. Cannabinoid – Incorrect:
  • • Cannabinoids (such as those found in marijuana) generally cause euphoria, drowsiness, increased heart rate, and conjunctival injection (red eyes), but they do not typically produce the anticholinergic symptoms described. While cannabinoid toxicity can lead to altered mental status, it does not typically cause dilated pupils and dry skin as seen with dhatura poisoning.

questions.text: A 36 week pregnant patient on warfarin. INR level is 3.Best Course of action would be
questions.correct_answer: D. Stop warfarin switch to heparin
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Aspirin is not typically used as a sole anticoagulant in pregnancy, particularly in this case, where the patient is on warfarin and has an elevated INR. Adding aspirin alone is not sufficient for anticoagulation, especially in patients requiring a more effective therapy for conditions like deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism.
  • • B. Aspirin + Heparin – Incorrect:
  • • While heparin is appropriate for anticoagulation during pregnancy, adding aspirin is typically used in specific conditions like preeclampsia, recurrent pregnancy loss, or for antiplatelet effects in certain cardiovascular conditions. It is not needed in this case, and the priority should be stopping warfarin and starting heparin.
  • • C. Continue warfarin – Incorrect:
  • • Continuing warfarin is not recommended during pregnancy, especially in the third trimester, due to the risk of fetal bleeding and teratogenicity. The best approach is to stop warfarin immediately and switch to heparin.

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling in the groin region and it is diagnosed as a direct inguinal hernia. Weakness in which of the following structures is most likely to cause this condition?

A patient presents with sudden onset of hematemesis. He has been taking aspirin for his arthritis and drinks alcohol occasionally. He gives a history of occasional abdominal pain. On examination, there is no abdominal mass or tenderness. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The most likely diagnosis is peptic ulcer disease (PUD). This condition often presents with upper gastrointestinal bleeding manifested as hematemesis, especially in individuals with known risk factors. The patient has a history of aspirin use, which is a common cause of mucosal injury leading to ulcer formation due to its inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis, reducing gastric mucosal protection. Additionally, occasional alcohol consumption can irritate the gastric mucosa and exacerbate ulceration. The history of abdominal pain supports the diagnosis, as ulcers often cause epigastric discomfort. The absence of abdominal tenderness or mass does not exclude ulcer-related bleeding, as many ulcers can bleed silently until significant hemorrhage occurs. Therefore, the clinical picture is most consistent with a bleeding peptic ulcer. A. Mallory-Weiss tear – Incorrect. This condition involves a longitudinal mucosal tear at the gastroesophageal junction, typically following forceful vomiting or retching, leading to hematemesis. The absence of preceding vomiting or retching in this case makes this diagnosis less likely. B. Esophagitis – Incorrect. Esophagitis may present with mild bleeding, dysphagia, or odynophagia, but it rarely causes significant hematemesis. It is more commonly associated with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) or immunosuppressed states (e.g., candida or viral esophagitis), which are not present in this case. D. Esophageal varices – Incorrect. While esophageal varices are a serious cause of upper GI bleeding, they are typically seen in patients with chronic liver disease and portal hypertension. There is no evidence of liver dysfunction in this patient, and occasional alcohol use without signs of cirrhosis or chronic liver disease makes this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A construction worker came to the OPD complaining of white fingers. He has been working in the cement and concrete industry and has been working on heavy machinery drills, wood, and furniture polishing for 20 years. What is the most likely etiology for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water

options.label: C
options.text: Continuous exposure to cement and concrete

options.label: D
options.text: Continuous exposure to drills and machines

questions.correct_answer: D. Continuous exposure to drills and machines

questions.text: A 5 year old child was admitted to the hospital for prolapsing rectal mass and painless rectal bleeding. Histopathological examination reveals enlarged and inflamed glands filled with mucin. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The most likely diagnosis is a hamartoma, specifically a juvenile (retention) polyp, which is the most common type of rectal polyp in children and young adults. These lesions are benign, disorganized overgrowths of tissue normally found in the affected area. Clinically, they present with painless rectal bleeding and prolapse, as described in the case. On histopathology, juvenile polyps typically show dilated, cystically enlarged glands filled with mucin, often with inflammatory cells in the stroma, which aligns with the findings of enlarged and inflamed glands filled with mucin. These features are classic for a hamartomatous polyp, confirming option C as the correct answer. A. Adenoma – Incorrect. An adenoma is a neoplastic lesion with potential for malignant transformation, usually seen in older adults. Histologically, adenomas show dysplastic epithelium, not simply mucin-filled glands with inflammation. Adenomas are less common in young patients and typically not associated with prolapse. B. Choristoma – Incorrect. A choristoma is a mass of normal tissue in an abnormal location (ectopic tissue). This does not fit the clinical or histological picture, as the rectal mass in this case is made of tissue normally found in the rectum, just disorganized — which is consistent with a hamartoma, not a choristoma. D. Carcinoma – Incorrect. Carcinoma implies malignant epithelial transformation, with features such as invasion, cellular atypia, and mitotic figures. The histology here does not show dysplasia or invasion, and the clinical presentation in a 25-year-old with painless bleeding and prolapse also does not support carcinoma, which is rare at this age.

questions.text: Identify the given condition-
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A trophic ulcer, also known as a neuropathic ulcer, is caused by loss of sensation due to nerve damage, commonly from conditions like diabetes mellitus, leprosy, or spinal cord injuries. The key characteristics include painless ulceration, typically over pressure points (such as the heel, sole, or metatarsal heads), and deep, punched-out appearance with a surrounding area of callus or dry skin. These ulcers develop due to repetitive unnoticed trauma and poor wound healing secondary to lack of protective sensation. The chronic nature, absence of pain, and location over pressure points strongly point toward a trophic ulcer, making option D the correct diagnosis. A. Venous ulcer – Incorrect. Venous ulcers usually occur around the medial malleolus (ankle) and are associated with varicose veins, leg swelling, and hyperpigmentation. They are typically shallow, irregular in shape, and surrounded by edema and skin changes like lipodermatosclerosis. These features are not mentioned or implied in this case. B. Malignant ulcer – Incorrect. Malignant ulcers (e.g., Marjolin’s ulcer or ulcerating cancers) often have raised, everted edges, are non-healing, and may be associated with bleeding, foul discharge, or regional lymphadenopathy. The description lacks such suggestive malignant features or systemic signs. C. Arterial ulcer – Incorrect. Arterial ulcers typically appear on toes, feet, or other pressure areas, and are painful, with punched- out edges, and the surrounding skin is often cold, pale, and hairless due to poor arterial blood supply. The presence of pain is a distinguishing factor, which is usually absent in trophic ulcers due to neuropathy.

questions.text: A patient with varicose veins comes with complaints of eczema over the same region. What is the stage of the clinical classification according to the CEAP guidelines?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • According to the CEAP classification system for chronic venous disorders, the "C" in CEAP stands for clinical classification. C4a specifically refers to skin changes due to venous disease, including eczema (also called stasis dermatitis) and pigmentation. In this case, the patient with varicose veins presents with eczema over the same area, which is a classic skin change associated with chronic venous insufficiency. These skin manifestations are due to venous hypertension, leading to capillary leakage, hemosiderin deposition, and inflammatory responses in the skin. Therefore, C4a is the correct classification, as it directly refers to venous eczema and pigmentation without ulceration. A. C2 – Incorrect. C2 refers only to the presence of varicose veins without any associated edema, skin changes, or ulcers. Since this patient has developed eczema, the condition has progressed beyond C2. B. C3 – Incorrect. C3 denotes the presence of edema in association with venous disease, but without skin changes such as eczema or pigmentation. The presence of eczema elevates the classification beyond this stage. D. C4b – Incorrect. C4b refers to more severe skin changes, such as lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche, which are not mentioned in this scenario. Since only eczema is described, it fits within C4a, not C4b.

questions.text: A patient comes to the casualty with severe headache. His BP was found to be 160/100mmHg. CT scan revealed a subarachnoid hemorrhage. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The next best step in the management of a patient with a confirmed subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is the administration of Nimodipine, a calcium channel blocker. Nimodipine has been shown to significantly reduce the risk of delayed cerebral ischemia and vasospasm, which are major causes of morbidity and mortality following SAH. It is typically started as early as possible after diagnosis and continued for 21 days. While it does not treat the hemorrhage itself, it plays a crucial role in preventing secondary complications and improving neurologic outcomes. Thus, initiating Nimodipine is the most appropriate and immediate pharmacological intervention after confirming SAH. B. Angiography – Incorrect. While cerebral angiography is important for identifying the source of bleeding (e.g., ruptured aneurysm), it is not the immediate next step. Stabilization and prevention of complications like vasospasm with Nimodipine take precedence before invasive investigations. C. Surgery – Incorrect. Surgical intervention (e.g., clipping or endovascular coiling of the aneurysm) is a definitive treatment but is typically done after initial stabilization and imaging to localize the source. It is not the immediate next step after the CT diagnosis, especially before administering measures to prevent vasospasm. D. Fibrinolytic therapy – Incorrect. Fibrinolytics (e.g., tPA) are contraindicated in hemorrhagic strokes, including subarachnoid hemorrhage, as they would worsen bleeding. Their use in this setting would be dangerous and is never appropriate.

questions.text: A 20 year old female patient consumed a cleaning product containing 90% sodium hydroxide. She is having complete dysphagia. What is the best step in management?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Ingestion of strong caustic agents like sodium hydroxide can cause severe damage to the esophagus, leading to complete dysphagia (inability to swallow). The best immediate management in this case, after stabilizing the patient and addressing any acute injuries (such as airway protection, fluid resuscitation, and pain management), is to establish nutritional support. A feeding jejunostomy (J-tube) is typically recommended in patients who have severe esophageal injury or strictures, and are unable to maintain oral intake due to dysphagia. It allows for enteral feeding bypassing the damaged esophagus and providing nutritional support until the patient can recover or the esophagus can be treated or repaired. This is the most appropriate step in managing long-term nutritional needs. A. Esophagojejunostomy – Incorrect. Esophagojejunostomy involves creating a direct anastomosis between the esophagus and the jejunum, which is generally used in cases where esophageal resection is performed due to severe malignancy or extensive damage. In this case, complete dysphagia due to caustic ingestion is better managed with feeding via a jejunostomy tube before considering such extensive procedures. B. Stent placement – Incorrect. Stent placement may be used for palliative management of esophageal strictures in certain situations (such as cancer or benign stenosis), but it is not the first-line treatment in the acute setting of caustic ingestion. The priority here is nutritional support and treating the esophageal injury, which stents would not address effectively in this scenario. D. Gastrojejunostomy – Incorrect. Gastrojejunostomy is typically performed in cases of gastric outlet obstruction or intractable gastric issues, and is not appropriate for managing caustic esophageal injury. The goal in this case is to bypass the damaged esophagus, and a feeding jejunostomy is a more direct and suitable approach.

questions.text: A 23 year old patient presents with midline swelling in the neck. The swelling moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The most likely diagnosis is a thyroglossal cyst. These cysts are the most common congenital neck masses and are typically located along the midline of the neck, specifically at the level of the hyoid bone or along the path of the embryological descent of the thyroid gland. The key features that point to this diagnosis are: Midline location of the swelling.
  • • The swelling moves with swallowing (deglutition) and protrusion of the tongue, as it is connected to the tongue via the thyroglossal duct. This duct is a remnant of the thyroid gland’s descent during embryogenesis. The movement of the swelling with tongue protrusion is a hallmark feature of thyroglossal cysts. A. Brachial cyst – Incorrect. A brachial cyst typically presents as a lateral neck mass, usually anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle. It does not move with swallowing or tongue protrusion, as it is not connected to the tongue or swallowing muscles. It is generally not found in the midline, ruling out this diagnosis in this case. C. Plunging ranula – Incorrect. A plunging ranula is a type of mucocele that arises from the sublingual gland and typically presents as a swelling in the submandibular region or along the floor of the mouth. Though it can be mobile, it does not typically move with tongue protrusion in the same way as a thyroglossal cyst and is more commonly lateral in location. D. Dermoid cyst – Incorrect. A dermoid cyst is a benign cystic mass that can occur in various locations, including the head and neck. It is generally midline but is non-mobile and does not move with swallowing or tongue protrusion. Dermoid cysts typically contain skin structures like hair follicles and sebaceous glands, which is not consistent with the typical presentation of a thyroglossal cyst.

questions.text: A 54 year old woman presents with cervical cancer stage 2A. It is decided to give neoadjuvant chemotherapy. What does neoadjuvant chemotherapy mean?

Which of the following laboratory test is used to diagnose rotavirus diarrhea?

questions.correct_answer: A. Antigen detection in the stool sample

questions.text: A boy presented with fever and chills. Rapid test was positive for specific antigen HRP-2. Which of the following species of Plasmodium is the most likely causative agent?

A child was brought with complaints of high fever, multiple seizures, headache and rigidity. CSF analysis showed low glucose, high protein, and many polymorphs. The CSF culture showed pleomorphic gram-negative bacilli. What is true about the causative organism?

questions.correct_answer: C. Exhibits satellitism around Staph aureus colonies

questions.text: A patient presented with high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity and seizures. He was diagnosed with HSV encephalitis. Which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.correct_answer: C. CSF PCR for viral DNA

questions.text: In a patient presented with a fever and a positive filarial antigen test, what is the next appropriate method of management?

options.label: C
options.text: Detection of microfilariae in the blood smear

questions.correct_answer: C. Detection of microfilariae in the blood smear

questions.text: A man presents with a history of dysuria and urethral discharge after having unprotected sexual intercourse. Gram staining of the purulent discharge is seen in the following image. What is the treatment of choice for this infection?
Which of the following zymogens requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase?

A young boy presents to OPD with hypoglycemia and muscle cramps while playing. Then he becomes normal after resting for some time. These episodes are recurrent after activity. He has decreased serum lactate and glucose levels. Which of the following diseases is he most likely suffering from?
A family who consumes only polished rice will which of the following combinations of vitamin deficiency and enzymatic defect?
A chronic alcoholic patient presented to the casualty with confusion, ataxia and painful eye movements. What could be the vitamin deficiency seen in this patient?

A 4 year old child presents with easy fatiguability. The mother complains that the child has increased hunger between meals, which is relieved after food. Liver examination revealed no glycogen. The enzyme likely to be deficient is?
A child was brought with pedal edema and cheilosis. Cardiomegaly was present. What is the vitamin deficiency associated with this clinical presentation?
A chronic alcoholic patient is diagnosed with gouty arthritis. What biochemical changes will be seen in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. Increased urate and lactate levels

questions.text: A child presents with erythematous scaly patches in the perioral region, mucosal ulcers and impaired epithelial wound healing. The likely mineral deficiency associated with this condition is-
A patient presenting with bleeding gums and easy bruisability was diagnosed with scurvy. This is due to-
Which of the following is seen in low inulin:glucagon ratio?
An infant is brought by his parents with complaints that his urine turns black on standing. Which of the following metabolic disorders is likely?
A child presents with bone pain and hepatosplenomegaly. A trephine biopsy and aspirate shows the following finding. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme deficient in this condition?
A child presents with thinning of hair and scaling of the scalp. On taking history, it is found that she consumes raw eggs in her diet. Which vitamin deficiency is likely?
A child presents with mental retardation, bone pain, and inability to walk. On fundoscopy examination, a cherry red spot is seen. There is no organomegaly. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is true regarding Mendelian mode of inheritance?

options.label: A
options.text: Every 10th patient has a Y-linked disorder

options.label: B
options.text: 1/3rd of Mendelian disorders are Autosomal recessive

options.label: C
options.text: Every 5th patient has an X-linked disorder

options.label: D
options.text: 2/3rds of Mendelian disorders are autosomal dominant

questions.correct_answer: D. 2/3rds of Mendelian disorders are autosomal dominant

questions.text: An elderly male, known smoker presented with chronic cough, significant weight loss and fatigue. Serum calcium level is raised. A lung biopsy showed large atypical cells with hyperchromasia. What is the probable diagnosis?

A young patient presents with large retroperitoneal hemorrhage. He also gives a frequent history of intermittent swelling of knees on strenuous exercise. There is no history of any mucosal bleed. Which among the following clotting factors is responsible for the above mentioned condition?
Lab investigations of an elderly male shows marked elevation of lymphocytes with marked leucocytosis. The peripheral smear is given below. What is the appropriate next step for the patient?
A 23 year old male presented with low Hb, platelet count of 25,000/ml, gum bleeding, and raised PT and Aptt. The image of his peripheral smear is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
A chronic smoker who worked in the cement factory for the past 20 years developed mesothelioma. The association is likely due to –

A child presents with intermittent jaundice and splenomegaly. There is a history of similar complaints in the elder brother. Peripheral blood smear shows the following finding. How will you investigate this condition?
questions.correct_answer: A. Osmotic fragility test- Hereditary spherocytosis

questions.text: An African child is found to have a mass in the jaw. A biopsy of the mass is done and it appears as shown in the image below. The child also has a translocation of t(8;14). What is the probable diagnosis?

A child presented with cola-coloured urine, hypertension, and puffiness of eyes. Lab investigations were done and creatinine was 2.5mg/dl. Treatment was started and despite treatment, the patient did not improve for the next 3 weeks. The creatinine value increased to 4.5mg/dl. Which among the following electron microscopic findings will be seen in this patient?
A patient was transfused 4 units of blood 2 hours ago, and now she complains of chest discomfort. X-ray shows bilateral fissural thickening. Which of the following is the most probable cause?

A 45 year old man presents with complaints of facial puffiness, frothy urine, and hypertension. He gives a history of infection with hepatitis B. Urine examination reveals microscopic hematuria. The histopathological image of the kidney biopsy shows a spike and dome pattern. What is the diagnosis of this condition?
A 5 year old child is brought with fever, fatigue and left ventricular dysfunction. An endomyocardial biopsy is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
10 year child presents with generalised edema, cholesterol is increased, urine protein 3+, urine microscopy shows oval fat bodies. Likely diagnosis?

50-year-old male c/o fatiguability persistent for one year. Mild anaemia massive spleenomegaly hb 10gm% tlc of 120*10(3) platelet 500*10(3) neutrophils 60, basophil 4, eosinophil 5 lymph 15 myleoblast 3 rest were myelocyte and bands. M: E ratio of 18: 1 most specific further investigation
